text: Now, these versions of the verb that we get after haber, and we said that it's any version of haber, whether it's e, whether it's había, whether it's habría, we could even say I will have, I will have lost it, lo habré perdido.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Any version of haber, we will have the version afterwards.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Even if it's in the to form, we could say something like I would like to have gone.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: I would like to have gone.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: I would like, it would please me, to have gone.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It would please me to have gone.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: I would like to have gone.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So even after the to form, we're having just one version of the verb that can come after haber.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, this version of the verb that can come after haber is very useful because if it makes sense, we can use it as an adjective, just as we can in English.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: For example, in English, we say, I have sold.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And sold, we can use like an adjective.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We can say, it is sold.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And we can use it like an adjective.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And you can do the same in Spanish, which gives you hundreds and hundreds of words now that you can access as adjectives.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So for example, to close is cerrar.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say, I have closed it.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You might be referring to the door, which is la puerta.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So if you were referring to the door, how would you say that?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So cerrado, we can take that and we can use it as an adjective.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, it doesn't change ever after haber.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But when it's an adjective, when it's behaving like an adjective, then of course it can change.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So if you say, it is closed, and you mean the door, how will you say it?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would you say that?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Do you think to be closed is a state or a characteristic?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: In fact, the great majority, with just a couple of exceptions of these adjectives that we get from adoído, that we get from the version that comes after haber, go with a star.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: With this particular type of adjective, we don't need to really think about whether it's a state or a characteristic.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: They're just going to go with a star, with a couple of exceptions.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What is the that comes after haber, after any form of haber?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would you say, I am lost?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Estoy perdido, or for feminine, perdida.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What was to finish or to terminate?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say, I have finished?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So now you can also say, it is finished, and use it like an adjective.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What if you were referring to the movie, which is la película?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So this gives us a lot of adjectives we can access.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Let's have a look at some of them.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: To sell was vender, and then sold would be?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And if we mean las casas, how would it sound?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Some of the adjectives that we already met are actually adjectives that were formed in this way.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How was the word for tired?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And this comes from the verb cansar, to tire.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So cansar is to tire, and then cansado is the version that you get after haber, and it's the adjective.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So if you want to say I get tired, I tire myself.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: That means I get tired or even I get fed up.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say I have tired myself?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And like I said, it doesn't literally mean that you are responsible for tiring yourself.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It just means you've got tired, or you can use it like I've had enough.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And then cansado, which is the version of cansar after haber, is also of course the adjective tired.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So to close is cerar, and we said that closed is cerrado.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And we said that these ado, ido adjectives, with a couple of exceptions, go with estar.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how do you say it is closed?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say he is closed to the idea?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Idea is the same word in Spanish.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: He is closed to the idea.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What gender does it look like idea?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But if you want to say he's a closed person, you mean as a person he's closed, how do you think you would say it?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: This is exactly the structure that we want.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But the word for person is feminine, and it doesn't refer to anybody specifically.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Just the word itself is feminine.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So that's how we can get around that if we want to say he's closed, and we mean he's a closed person.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: If we just say es cerrado, it sounds like a mistake.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But es una persona cerrada is fine because es is going with persona.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What you're saying essentially is he is a person that is closed.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say she is lost?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But if you want to say she's lost, you know, as a person, she's lost her way.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: In this structure you're saying she is a person.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You're not looking at lost person, you're looking at person.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So when you say this is a chair, you're going to use ser.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: If you're going to say it's a wet chair, even though that is a state, you're still going to use ser.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Because what you're saying is it's a chair.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But if you say it is wet, then you use a star.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So chair or seat is silla.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now how do you think you say wet as an adjective?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would you say the chair, la silla, the chair is wet?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But if you say it is a wet chair, you're just saying it is a chair.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And then the adjective is secondary.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And the fact that it is a chair is about as characteristic as it gets.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So you're saying it is a chair.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So when we say something is a noun, when we give it its name, there's nothing more characteristic.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The structure there is it is a chair.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But when we say the chair is wet, then we are talking about a state of the chair with is.
speaker: Speaker 1
